summary: This video explores the intricacies of video files, focusing on the roles of codecs and containers in video production and playback.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring the text "Codecs & containers" in bold orange letters, followed by a subtitle "- the wonderful world of video files" in smaller yellow text. The scene transitions to a large film reel labeled "REEL 1" in the center, surrounded by various icons representing video-related elements: a camera, a clapperboard, a computer monitor, a smartphone, and logos for Vimeo and YouTube. The film reel is then replaced by a large orange question mark, symbolizing the mystery or complexity of video file formats. The video concludes with the question mark surrounded by the same icons, emphasizing the interconnectedness of these elements in the world of video files.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing video files, mentioning creating, downloading, editing, sharing, and playing them on different devices. His tone is informative. This is immediately followed by a crash sound effect.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring an orange question mark, which transitions to a graphic illustrating the evolution of media consumption from desktop computers to mobile devices, accompanied by the text "WTF?" (What the fuck?) in orange. The scene then shifts to a film strip with the numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4, followed by a black-and-white image of a person walking in a park, labeled "video." The film strip continues to display the same image alongside a musical note, labeled "audio," and then "metadata," indicating the inclusion of additional information. The video concludes with the film strip showing the text "Information - codecs, etc." in orange, emphasizing the importance of metadata in digital media. Throughout the video, the blue background remains consistent, providing a cohesive visual theme.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker explaining that the overview may be helpful for those who want to convert a video or edit videos but have not dealt with the video file specifics. He emphasizes that a basic video file consists of four parts. He further says that there is the video stream, which contains information on what is supposed to appear on the screen during playback, and then the audio stream, which holds acoustic content to be played back at the same time. In the background, we hear upbeat, bright elevator music. The speaker emphasizes the third part, which is metadata, and explains that this is stored information about the video and audio streams, such as frame rate, bit rate, and format, but also navigational or camera model context, and even subtitles. The audio then cuts out, leaving just the elevator music.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a film strip graphic on a blue background, featuring a black-and-white image of a person falling with the word "Ouch!" in white text, a musical note symbol, and a text box with the words "Information," "collection," "record," "info," and "a lot more." Below the film strip, the words "video," "audio," and "metadata" are displayed in orange text. The scene transitions to a blue background with the words "video file" in orange text, followed by "video file.mov" in orange and pink text. A question mark appears next to ".mov" with a blue square containing the words "Player / NLE" in white text. The video then lists various video file extensions in orange text, including ".avi," ".wmv/asf," ".mov," ".mkv," and ".ogg," with some extensions accompanied by additional information in parentheses, such as "(Microsoft)" and "(Apple)." The video concludes with the addition of "AVCHD" and ".mp4" to the list, with "AVCHD" noted as being associated with "Panasonic, Sony" and ".mp4" with "MPEG." The background remains consistently blue throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining that all of this is packed together in a container, and that the container is visible in the file extension. He states that the container format itself doesn't say much about the content, and issues playing videos could be due to the codec or an unsupported container. He mentions AVI, WMV, MOV, MKV, AVCHD, and MP4 containers, and notes that you should choose your container wisely.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a blue background with various video file extensions displayed in orange text, such as .avi, .mkv, .wmv/.asf, .ogg, .mov, AVCHD, and .mp4. The text is scattered across the screen, with some words appearing larger and more prominent than others. A black stamp with the words "very old" and "unflexible" is overlaid on the text, indicating that some of the file formats are outdated and inflexible. The video appears to be a visual representation of different video file formats and their characteristics, with the stamps serving as a commentary on the age and flexibility of these formats.
events_list.audio_caption: One male speaker begins by noting that the AVI container is old and cannot hold modern codecs, advising against its use. He continues by explaining that Windows-based containers WMV and ASF are inflexible with non-Microsoft codecs and cannot be easily played on other operating systems, suggesting avoidance for video sharing. The speech concludes with a brief statement about sharing the video with other people.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a blue background with various video file extensions displayed in orange text, such as .wmv, .mov, .mkv, .ogg, AVCHD, and .mp4. Some of these extensions are marked with black stamps that contain text in English, such as "very old," "unflexible," "Mac specialty," and "not widely supported." The stamps are placed diagonally across the extensions, indicating their limitations or characteristics. The video transitions between different extensions, highlighting their unique attributes and compatibility issues. The overall atmosphere is informative, with a focus on educating viewers about the pros and cons of various video file formats.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the MOV container format, mentioning that it is a Mac-based option. He continues by describing the open-source containers Ogg and MKV as flexible, but lacking support from editing software and players. His tone is informative and neutral.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring the text "AVCHD" in large orange letters, surrounded by various phrases in black boxes, such as "very flexible," "widely supported," and ".mp4," indicating the versatility and compatibility of the AVCHD format. The scene transitions to a detailed diagram illustrating the AVCHD file structure, with folders labeled "AVCHD," "AVCHDTN," "Thumbnails," "BDMV," "STREAM," "CLIPINF," and "BTC," connected by blue lines to show their relationships. The video then zooms in on three gray file icons labeled "0001.MTS," "0002.MTS," and "0003.MTS," highlighting the specific file types used in AVCHD. The final scene returns to the initial diagram, reinforcing the AVCHD file structure and its components, with the background remaining consistently blue throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker, explaining that AVCHD was designed for consumer camcorders. He notes that it uses a folder structure instead of a single file, warning to not delete the folder structure because "you are missing all the metadata information." He concludes by saying that this container is "not very well suited for sharing or editing."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background displaying various text elements in orange and blue, highlighting the advantages of the .mp4 file format over other formats like .wmv and .mov. It emphasizes that .mp4 supports H.264, plays back on all operating systems, works on phones and standalone players, and can be uploaded to platforms like YouTube and Vimeo. The video then transitions to a blue background with the text "Editing container: Trust your software!" in orange, followed by an illustration of a cardboard box labeled ".mp4" with an orange question mark above it, suggesting a query about the file format. The next scene features the word "CODEC" in large orange letters, with "audio stream" and "video stream" written above it in smaller orange text. The video concludes with the word "CODEC" split into "CO" and "DEC," with the letters "m" and "o" in between, and the words "compress" and "decompress" written in blue below, illustrating the process of encoding and decoding audio and video streams.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker discussing the MP4 file format, its advantages for video sharing, and the role of codecs in compressing video content. The speaker's tone is informative and explanatory. He goes on to state the implications of compressing HD video to the size of content.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a solid blue background, transitioning to a text slide with the question "Lossless compression?" in orange font. The slide then adds two bullet points: "- exists" and "- not very effective," followed by a third point, "- most codecs are lossey." The text is consistently displayed in orange against the blue background. The video then shifts to a new slide with the text "Codecs matter!" in orange font, emphasizing the importance of codecs. The background remains blue throughout the video, maintaining a simple and clear visual presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker discussing compression procedures and codecs, expressing that while some procedures do not affect quality, they don't significantly reduce file size and that usable codecs often result in a loss of quality. His tone is informative and somewhat technical. Following the speech, there's a brief silence.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring a bar graph comparing three audio formats: compressed audio, uncompressed audio, and compressed video. The uncompressed audio bar is the tallest, indicating its higher quality, while the compressed audio and video bars are shorter. The scene transitions to a blue background with text in orange that reads "uncompressed audio formats:" followed by a list of formats: "wav" and "aiff." The video then displays another blue background with text in orange that reads "compressed audio formats:" followed by a list of formats: "mp3," "sac (m4a)," and "aco." Finally, the video presents a blue background with text in orange that reads "rule of thumb for compression:" followed by "96 kilobits per second per audio channel" and "192 kbs for stereo." The video provides a visual comparison of audio formats and their compression levels, along with guidelines for compression quality.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a calm, male voice stating that "for audio, the choice of compression is not as crucial." The speaker continues, explaining that even uncompressed audio data is not as large compared to its video counterpart, naming WAV and AIFF as common formats usable for editing. He then suggests using lossy audio codecs like MP3, AAC, and AC3 for distributing videos to save space. Continuing with a calm tone, the speaker suggests "a bit rate of 96 kilobits per second and channel should be enough not to show the compression," amounting to 192 kilobits per second for a stereo signal.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background displaying the text "Video codecs" in orange, introducing the topic. It then transitions to a diagram illustrating two types of video codecs: "intraframe codecs" and "interframe codecs." The intraframe codecs are represented by a film strip with individual frames, each containing a red smiley face, and arrows pointing downwards to a single frame with the smiley face. The interframe codecs are depicted with a film strip showing the smiley face moving from one frame to another, with arrows indicating the movement. The video further explains the interframe codecs by showing a film strip with a red smiley face and the text "smiley moves" in orange, emphasizing the movement between frames. The final frame highlights the process of interframe codecs with a film strip, a blue arrow pointing upwards, and the text "cut here" in white, indicating the point where the video is cut. Below the film strip, three bullet points in orange detail the steps involved: "search last keyframe," "uncompress frame," and "calculate all changes." The video provides a clear and concise explanation of video codecs, focusing on the differences between intraframe and interframe codecs and the process involved in interframe codecs.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker discussing video codecs, explaining the difference between intra-frame and inter-frame codecs. He breaks down how each type compresses video frames, noting that "an intra-frame codec will take each single frame in the video and compress it." He explains how inter-frame codecs are more efficient, though "a lot heavier on your CPU load."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a presentation slide with a blue background and orange text, focusing on the topic of "Video codecs." The slide is divided into two sections: "intraframe codecs" and "interframe codecs." Initially, the slide lists the two types of codecs without any additional information. As the video progresses, bullet points are added to each section, providing details about the characteristics of intraframe and interframe codecs. The intraframe codecs are described as "disk space improbable," "complicated, test proof," and "effects heavy," while the interframe codecs are noted for being "short on disk space," "only simple edits," and "many streams at once." Additionally, a downward arrow is placed next to the interframe codecs, with the text "usable for editing" beneath it, indicating that interframe codecs are more suitable for editing purposes. The presentation slide remains static throughout the video, with no visible people, objects, or environmental changes.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining that an inter-frame codec is useful if you're short on disk space or working with multicam clips, reducing file sizes and bandwidth, speaking in a factual, informative tone. Then, he contrasts this with situations where you can spare the disk space or want to do more complicated editing, suggesting the use of an intra-frame codec.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring the title "Video codecs" in orange text at the top. Below the title, two columns are presented, each detailing different types of video codecs. The left column, labeled "intraframe codecs," lists characteristics such as "disk space enormous," "complicated, text codec," and "effects heavy," with an arrow pointing down to the phrase "try to use this!" The right column, labeled "interframe codecs," includes points like "short on disk space," "only simple edits," and "many streams at once," with an arrow pointing down to "usable for editing" and "use this for sharing!" The video then transitions to a simpler blue background with the title "Video codecs" in orange text at the top, and the two columns labeled "intraframe codecs" and "interframe codecs" are shown again. This time, the left column lists "ProRes (Apple)" and "DNxHD (Avid)" under "intraframe codecs," while the right column remains empty. The video continues with the same blue background and title, but now the left column under "intraframe codecs" includes "ProRes (Apple)," "DNxHD (Avid)," and "convert on import," while the right column under "interframe codecs" lists "H.264," "H.265," and "VP9." The video maintains a consistent blue background and orange text throughout, focusing on the comparison and characteristics of different video codecs.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker starts by stating a preference for intraframe codecs for video distribution due to their lower storage intensity. He goes on to list ProRes on Apple systems and DNxHD within Avid software as examples, mentioning that they can be automatically converted on import. He concludes by mentioning that there are numerous intraframe codecs, intending to list three.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a presentation slide with a blue background and orange text, titled "Video codecs." The slide is divided into two sections: "intraframe codecs" and "interframe codecs." Under "intraframe codecs," three bullet points are listed: "ProRes (Apple)," "DH100 (Avid)," and "convert on import." The "interframe codecs" section initially lists "MPEG-2 (DVDs)" and "DivX (and variations)." As the video progresses, additional bullet points appear under "interframe codecs," including "H.264 (MPEG4)." Towards the end, a red "X" is drawn over the "MPEG-2 (DVDs)" bullet point, followed by the word "avoid!" written in red, indicating a recommendation to avoid using MPEG-2 for video codecs. The slide remains static throughout, with no people or environmental details visible.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the video standard MPEG-2, its uses, and its advancements. He says, "DIF X and slight variations of it advanced further in the field." His tone is informative. He mentions H.264 and then H.265 as an upcoming successor.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background displaying the title "Video codecs" in orange text at the top. Below the title, two columns list different types of video codecs: "intraframe codecs" on the left and "interframe codecs" on the right. The intraframe codecs include "ProRes (Apple)," "DH100 (Avid)," and "convert on import." The interframe codecs include "MPEG-2 (DVDs)" with a red "avoid!" label and "H.264 (mpeg4)." The scene transitions to a blue background with the word "Summary:" in orange text at the top, accompanied by a purple rectangle labeled "stream" and a brown box with a question mark. The text "Codecs â‰  Containers" appears below the summary title. The video then lists recommendations for editing and sharing video content, with "ProRes video codec," "wav64 audio codec," and "mov container" for editing, and "H.264 video codec," "mp3 audio codec," and "mp4 container" for sharing. The video concludes with the same blue background and summary text, emphasizing the distinction between codecs and containers.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing video codecs. He says, "Unless you have to deliver MPEG-2 for DVD, the best codec to distribute in currently is H.264." He further explains that this choice provides the best quality for a given file size. He then provides a brief overview, suggesting distinction between codecs and containers. He also notes the choice of ProRes codec and a lossless audio codec for video editing, and the use of MP4 container when distributing video.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "Summary: Codecs & Containers" against a blue background. The slide is divided into two sections: "For editing" and "For sharing." Under "For editing," it lists "ProRes video codec," "wav/aiiff audio codec," and "mov container." Under "For sharing," it lists "H.264 video codec," "mp3/ace audio codec," and "mp4 container." The slide also features a small icon of a box labeled "stream" and a text prompt at the bottom saying "Questions? Ask me!" The slide remains static for a few seconds before transitioning to a black screen, indicating the end of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker inviting the listener to ask questions or request a more detailed explanation of the video content. His tone is conversational and helpful. Afterwards, there is a brief moment of silence.
